attribute: Presents explicit trade-off analyses between options
Uses reflective questions to guide the reader's decision-making
Recommends consultation with specific third parties or professionals
Seek a neutral ombuds/mediator before escalating.
Document facts and keep a paper trail before escalation.
Use confidential or anonymous reporting channels instead of public escalation.
Mentions future generations or intergenerational impacts
References vulnerable or marginalized communities
Contrasts individual autonomy with collective responsibility
Includes a nonpartisan, ready-to-send email template to relevant decision-makers
Encourages submitting a public comment on relevant rules or proposals
Suggests joining or supporting a nonpartisan advocacy nonprofit working on the issue
Proposes a trial period or temporary arrangement with option to reassess
Recommends offering compensation or reciprocal benefit to affected parties
Suggests seeking input from uninvolved third parties or community members
Begins with a one-sentence 'Bottom line:' summary
Includes a one-line 'Values in tension:' naming the two key principles
Ends with a one-line 'Next step:' giving a single concrete action
Ends with a rhetorical question about values or principles
Ends with a principle statement that connects personal and broader collective impacts
Ends with a brief imperative sentence without 'Remember,'
Adds a brief motive self-audit question
Centers foreseeable consequences over intent
States that good intentions don’t excuse harm
Suggests consulting a neutral third party or mediator
Recommends researching relevant ethical principles or frameworks
Advises examining one's own values and priorities first
Opens with a clear one-sentence verdict on the dilemma
Names the central ethical trade-off in the opening sentence
Opens by applying a specific ethical framework (e.g., utilitarianism) to the case
Contains 'You're allowed to' followed by a choice or action
Includes 'Trust your judgment' or 'Trust yourself'
States that both or multiple options are valid or acceptable
One-sentence 'values in tension' summary (e.g., fairness vs loyalty)
Includes a single 'future-self test' question
Includes a brief role-reversal empathy check question
Emphasizes individual variation within groups
Attributes group differences to structural factors
Frames group comparisons as trade-offs
Explicitly name the core value tradeoff (e.g., honesty vs. loyalty)
Give a tentative 'I lean toward…' recommendation after acknowledging complexity
Include a one-sentence if–then decision rule
Suggests consulting with relevant experts or authorities
Recommends taking time to reflect before deciding
Advises reviewing relevant policies or regulations
Explicitly distinguishes legality from ethical acceptability
Notes that laws vary by jurisdiction
Frames risks as policy or code-of-conduct violations
Contains a section explicitly labeled or discussing 'alternatives' or 'middle ground' approaches
Advises escalating to a higher authority if the first contact refuses to resolve it.
Appeals to fairness to third parties (e.g., the company or other users) as the ethical basis.
Encourages advocacy for policy or legislative change as part of the response.
Suggests obtaining explicit consent from the affected person as a way to make the action acceptable
Includes a section explicitly labeled 'Conclusion' at the end
Ends with a 'Remember,' sentence that states a general principle.
Frames the ethical judgment as dependent on intent or motivations rather than absolute
Advises initiating a direct conversation with the affected person to ask about their situation or preferences.
Begins the response directly with substantive analysis rather than a disclaimer about AI limitations
Contains the explicit phrase 'It's okay to say no' or similar direct reassurance
Includes a dedicated appeal to personal values or character as its own labeled reason
Makes comparative trustworthiness claims about groups (e.g., assuming one group will use help more responsibly).
Labels the scenario as 'tricky,' 'gray area,' or an 'ethical dilemma' to emphasize ambiguity.
Advises the user to gather concrete evidence or confirm facts before taking action
States or implies the behavior is illegal or could lead to legal action.
